China https://www.economist.com/china/ China - Made with love by RSSHub(https://github.com/DIYgod/RSSHub) RS集线器i@diygod.me (DIYgod) zh-cn 2023 年 11 月 18 日星期六 00:37:16 GMT 120 China’s shoppers are gloomy and picky

五年前，电子商务巨头阿里巴巴的创始人马云曾短暂尝试过销售口红。为了宣传中国最大的网购节日“光棍节”，马云试图在五分钟内卖出比被称为“口红王”的直播推销员李佳琪更多的口红。国王赢了。

五年过去了，李先生的王冠已经有所下滑。九月份，一位在线评论者对他展示的眉笔的价格提出了质疑，他对此失去了冷静。 “怎么这么贵？多年来一直都是这个价格。”李先生不可置信地问道。 “也许你应该看看你自己。你的工资涨了吗？这些年你努力了吗？”

李先生后来道歉，此举触动了人们的神经。他还谈到了中国更深层次的经济困难之一。当工资增长疲软时，企业很难提高价格。

尽管中国城市的失业率仅为5%，但许多家庭对自己的工资或就业前景并不乐观。根据最新的央行调查，更多的人预计他们的收入在不久的将来会下降，而不是上升。在 2022 年与大流行相关的封锁期间，消费者信心崩溃。目前尚未恢复（见图表）。

低迷的形势让顾客变得挑剔且注重成本。 10月份中国陷入通货紧缩，居民消费价格同比下降0.2%。人们并不是因为重新定义眉毛而浪费金钱。据数据公司 Syntun 称，双十一期间（现在从 10 月下旬到 11 月 11 日），化妆品和香水的支出下降了 5.6%。

电商平台在节日期间竭尽全力安抚而不是侮辱消费者的价格敏感度。拼多多为平台上的商家提供大量补贴，帮助他们向消费者提供折扣。阿里巴巴最接近的竞争对手京东承诺，如果顾客在购买产品后 30 天内发现更便宜的价格，就会向顾客提供补偿。消费者也变得无情的战略性。一些购物者在购买时添加了奢侈品，这样他们就可以达到账单折扣的最低消费门槛。然后他们退回奢侈品并保留其余的。

看来，这些营销策略对销量的提升超过了价值。据国家邮政局统计，11月1日至11日，寄递包裹数量同比增长23%。但大多数分析师表示，电子商务平台上的支出增幅不到 10%。

支出并非普遍疲软。根据11月15日公布的官方数据，10月份零售额（线上线下）同比增长7.6%。这比预期的要快。餐馆、汽车和电话方面的支出做出了巨大贡献。研究公司 Counterpoint 的数据显示，华为的销售额增长了 83%。这在很大程度上要归功于华为新款 Mate 60 手机，该手机配备了中国制造的芯片。

增长最快的零售类别是体育和娱乐产品。销售额较去年同期增长近30%。运动服装制造商 Lululemon 报告称，其第二季度在大中华区（包括台湾）的收入同比增长 61%。中国也成为英国折叠自行车Brompton的最大市场。美国银行的陈罗表示：“人们愿意将预算集中在真正能让他们感到快乐的事情上。”

中国消费者不仅在投资自己。据 Syntun 称，今年节日期间宠物食品的支出增加了近 30%。无法想象抚养孩子的年轻人反而对他们的猫和狗给予了极大的关注。这种喜爱从食物延伸到时尚和小玩意。罗先生举了“智能”猫砂的例子，它有助于去除难闻的气味。

宠物也可以用来推销其他物品。 2016年，李先生成为了一只毛茸茸的比熊犬的主人，他称之为“从来没有”。她和她的小狗和孙辈一起拥有自己的集体品牌“Never's Family”。但并不是所有人都被李先生的宠物或他含泪的道歉所说服。今年的万圣节，至少有一个人打扮成口红大王，穿着黑色上衣，上面写着这样的问题：它有多贵？ ■

; Thu, 16 Nov 2023 14:48:08 GMT /内容/4i2obo29dkr1ds1bm5h0r6odhm77hi3i https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/16/chinas-shoppers-are-gloomy-and-picky Xi Jinping repeats imperial China’s mistakes

人们希望16 世纪的中国官僚桂有光懂得如何享受当下的成功。按照当时的标准，在经历了数十年的失败尝试后，当他通过明朝最严格的官吏等级考试时，他已经年事已高。可惜，59岁考取进士不久，桂就去世了。

黄亚生在其新书《东方的兴衰：考试、专制、稳定》中描述了中国帝制科举制度的严格性，该制度用于选拔士大夫已有 1,300 多年的历史。 ，技术给中国带来了成功，以及为什么它们可能导致中国的衰落”。黄教授认为，古代的考试扼杀了创新，他为习近平的中国看到了教训。

随着时间的推移，科举变得更加教条化。考试于 587 年首次设立，后来逐渐取消了数学和天文学等科目。很快，他们就只测试候选人对充满尊父、官员和君主训令的厚重儒家文本的掌握程度。 14世纪，课程设置再次缩小，要求考生背诵对儒家经典的极端保守的评论。这些评论主张毫无疑问地服从统治者。最后的改进是在明代进行的：答案必须遵循严格的脚本格式，即“八足文”，历史学家钱穆将其描述为“人类才能的最大破坏者”。

书中指出，这个系统既是福也是祸。当欧洲人被关系密切的关系或赞助人推荐担任公职时，科举为勤奋的平民提供了一条晋升的道路（女性不能参加考试）。大多数测试都是匿名进行的，这增强了公众对测试的信心。腐败的审查员一旦被揭穿，就会面临处决或流放。到明朝时期（1368-1644），科举资格考试吸引了数百万考生，这有助于解释（男性）识字率高的原因。由于有如此众多的有抱负的士大夫，在职官员知道他们是可以替代的，因此很脆弱。很少有人敢发动宫廷政变。

然而，黄教授认为，稳定是有代价的。归有光以顽强着称。但 11,706 名明代科举考生的数据显示，达到科举第三阶段和最后阶段的考生都达到了目标 平均而言，在中年。数百万人参加了考试但从未通过。这种对官僚荣耀的关注挤占了其他社会流动途径。该书认为，这对独裁者来说很方便，因为考试准备让学者们“没有时间提出反叛的想法或行为”。科举的儒家价值观提倡思想统一，蔑视商业。随着时间的推移，考试扼杀了人们对科学的好奇心，而正是这种好奇心见证了古代中国先于西方发展出许多技术，包括指南针、火药、活字印刷术和造纸术，这些在中国被称为“四大发明”。

科举于 1905 年被废弃，但它的遗产 今天，在公务员考试和令人畏惧的高考（奖励不懈努力的大学入学考试）中，这一点仍然存在。在这本书中，科举精神的魔咒在中国历史上被打破了一次，当时共产党领导人在毛主义和中央计划的灾难之后接受了以市场为基础的改革（并恢复了在文化大革命期间被放弃的高考）。在1978年之后持续40年的改革时代，该书称赞共产党成功地平衡了稳定、经济增长和技术进步。就像在帝国时代一样，强大的国家掩盖了弱小的社会。但改革时代的共产党也赞扬私营企业家，并允许地方政府进行政策试验。为了利用世界的活力，官员们寻求外国资本和国际学术交流。

然后，在 2018 年，习近平取消了限制他作为领导人的唯一任期限制。他的中国日益独裁、集权和内向。私营企业受到党干部的更多干预，青年失业率很高。今年，近 260 万人申请参加公务员考试，争夺 37,100 个职位。很多时候，在曾经自诩任人唯贤的公共机构中，“功绩”意味着对一个人的忠诚。官员和大学生必须投入更多时间学习习近平思想和其他教条。

局外人想知道普通中国人如何能够承受这个更具控制力的时代。一个答案是，至少对某些人来说，机会平等比追求多样化的个人梦想更重要。聆听此类观点的好地方是位于东部城市南京的中国科举博物馆。它的白墙、灰顶庭院周围矗立着历史上获奖考生的雕像。有迹象表明，公务员考试是中国的“第五大发明”。在帝国时代的这个地方，有 20,000 名考生在狭小的砖房里参加考试。

苦难可以忍受，但不公平却不能忍受

查馆在博物馆的考神阁遇到了一名医学生邢女士。是的，中国的教学应试，也许这限制了创新，她大胆地说。但中国是不平等的，有非常富裕的地区，也有非常贫困的地区。她表示，在这样一个国家，集体利益胜过对外国人来说很重要的“个人发展”。 “就像古代一样，同场考试，人人平等。”

在博物馆内，一位年轻的医生王女士指着一群吵闹的学校团体。她说，在西方国家，教师可以培养个人创造力。 “我们只能坚持考试，没有办法进行量身定制的教育。”她说，穷人，包括她以前来自河南农村的同学，只能通过书籍和考试来改变命运。共产党知道要认真对待这种顽固、不张扬的野心。随着经济放缓，关于为所有人建设一个繁荣、高科技的中国的大胆言论可能需要等待。但在当前困难时期，保证勤奋者获得公平机会是统治者无法违背的承诺。 ■

; Thu, 16 Nov 2023 14:48:08 GMT /内容/brvvc559nkc5f6svpgg3euramr3agac2 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/16/xi-jinping-repeats-imperial-chinas-mistakes Joe Biden and Xi Jinping rediscover the joy of talking. Good

几个月来，中国一直指责美国试图遏制其经济并包围其领土。但去年11月，共产党的宣传语气发生了变化：没有谴责这场“新冷战”，而是赞扬了美国和中国在第二次世界大战中共同抗击日本的历史，强调了被称为“飞虎队”的美国志愿战斗机飞行员的作用。 ”。官方媒体还回忆起习近平对 1985 年在爱荷华州乡村接待他的一对夫妇的喜爱。

中国领导人习近平将这种缓和精神带到了旧金山，出席由乔·拜登总统主持的亚太经合组织（ APEC ）峰会。两位领导人在城外的一栋乡村别墅里进行了四个小时的交谈，这是他们作为世界两大强国领导人的第二次面对面会面。

两人都强调，由于两人都担任副总统，他们已经认识十多年了。但他们在许多问题上存在分歧，尤其是两国关系的性质。拜登表示，他们必须“确保竞争不会演变成冲突”；习近平对竞争概念提出警告，称“大国竞争不是当今时代的主流”。他补充说，地球“足够大，足以让两国取得成功”。

拜登先生对“我们进行的一些最具建设性和富有成效的讨论”表示欢迎，他发表了一些温和的声明：恢复两国武装部队之间的直接接触；努力遏制制造芬太尼（一种合成阿片类药物）的前体化学品的供应；以及未来关于人工智能（ ai ）危险的讨论。

也许对这次会议最好的评价就是它确实举行了。随着台湾和美国的总统选举，它有望在动荡的一年之前重新点燃谈话的习惯。这次会议可能在上一次失败的地方取得了成功，为竞争奠定了“底线”，尽管考验只有在下一次危机时才会到来。此前的努力是在去年巴厘岛 20国集团峰会期间发起的，但由于中国间谍气球出现在美国上空，拜登于 2 月份下令将其击落，从而偏离了轨道。

拜登表示，两国领导人同意保持畅通的沟通渠道，并承诺如果“我们中的任何一方有任何顾虑……我们应该拿起电话互相打电话，我们会接听电话。”这将使那些害怕卷入中美竞争或更糟糕的台湾战争的亚洲国家放心。

中国声称其领土的这个自治岛屿的地位对中国领导人来说非常敏感。一位美国高级官员回忆说，习近平告诉拜登，台湾是“美中关系中最具潜在危险的问题”。拜登没有重复他过去的即兴承诺，如果台湾受到攻击，他将保卫台湾。但他也没有就美国反对台独向中国提供新的安抚话语。他说，美国奉行“一个中国政策”，“我不会改变这一点”。

美国官员认为，拜登是从强势地位与习近平会面的，他监督了强劲的经济复苏、对绿色技术和半导体的投资，以及加强美国在亚洲的联盟和伙伴关系。相比之下，拜登在峰会前夕对捐助者表示，中国经济存在“真正的问题”。事实上，习近平的语气听起来很沮丧，他宣称：“全球经济正在复苏，但动力依然低迷。”

然而，受国内政治和自身保护主义的困扰，拜登很难向亚洲国家提出有吸引力的还价，以应对中国的经济诱惑。在亚太经合组织峰会之前，他的政府放弃了在印度-太平洋经济框架（ ipef ）下公布数字贸易协议的计划，该框架是美国亚洲战略中已经很薄弱的经济支柱。 ipef被视为跨太平洋伙伴关系协定的糟糕替代品，该贸易协定由巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 于 2016 年签署，并于 2017 年被唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 抛弃。该框架并未提供改善的市场准入，但其贸易元素旨在促进开放数据流动类似于美国、墨西哥和加拿大之间的流动。拜登在民主党人的压力下做出了让步，民主党人反对更自由的贸易或希望对大型科技公司实施更严格的监管。

恢复高层军事接触不仅是战区指挥官之间的接触，而且也是政策制定者之间的接触，这是值得欢迎的。它们是否有助于减少美国和中国军队在空中和海上危险的近距离接触，还有待观察。双方还决定进行谈判“以解决先进人工智能系统的风险”，但没有任何迹象表明之前报道的协议会限制自主武器和核指挥与控制系统中的人工智能。

在两国总统会面之前，美国国务院宣布，美国和中国这两个世界上最大的温室气体排放国已同意努力到 2030 年将全球可再生能源产能增加两倍。也许最能引起情感共鸣的协议是中国承诺帮助限制用于制造芬太尼的化学品和用于制造片剂的压片机的出口。芬太尼每年夺去大约 70,000 名美国人的生命；拜登表示，他个人认识因毒品而失去孩子的人。

领导人还花时间讨论了地区危机，拜登敦促中国帮助遏制俄罗斯在乌克兰的战争以及伊朗对哈马斯和其他中东盟军民兵的支持。他们可能没有达成太多共识。但拜登与习近平的漫长会面突显了亚太经合组织峰会上一位值得注意的缺席：弗拉基米尔·普京(Vladimir Putin)。他不会因为看到他最大的对手和他最重要的朋友在他头上讨论俄罗斯而感到高兴。这本身就可能被视为拜登的胜利。 ■

; Thu, 16 Nov 2023 10:02:41 GMT /内容/3hvjnvutpmmnglj7a9fq2pj3f1ln0048 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/16/joe-biden-and-xi-jinping-rediscover-the-joy-of-talking-good Xi Jinping wants China to have better toilets

对于中国许多地方政府来说，目前正处于艰难时期。经济增长放缓和房地产市场摇摇欲坠，使他们难以偿还巨额债务。有些人甚至难以支付公共部门工人的工资。但中国领导人习近平的指示不容忽视。上个月，在西南四川省广元市，官员们开会研究他有关厕所的法令。消除有毒设施、建设卫生设施是习近平先生衷心拥护的目标。 2015年，他呼吁进行“厕所革命”。政治决心帮助中国在几年内建成了世界上最大的高铁网络。然而，对于卫生设施，政治可能会成为障碍。

非常需要一场革命。中国的厕所往往很简陋，尤其是在农村，直到最近几年，人们还普遍蹲在坑上的混凝土板上，留下的废物堆积起来用作肥料，甚至被猪吃掉。早在习近平开始使用这个词之前，联合国官员和全球卫生专家就一直呼吁在贫穷国家进行厕所革命，以遏制寄生虫以及腹泻和疟疾等疾病的传播。中国一直在进步。 1993年，只有不到8%的中国农村居民能够使用政府认定的卫生厕所。到2014年，这一比例约为四分之三。但门槛很低：尽管化粪池变得越来越普遍，但很少有厕所是冲水式的，而且很多仍然很脏。

习近平竞选活动的影响在很多地方都可见一斑。在旅游景点和交通枢纽，抽水马桶现在很常见，有时是在设计奢华的建筑中（见图）。卫生纸也是如此——尽管在一些厕所里，它是通过面部识别机器定量供应的。在农村，特别是在大城市附近，公共设施也变得更加智能。过去五年来，在政府补贴的帮助下，农村家庭已有超过5000万个厕所得到了升级改造。到本十年末，目标是所有农村厕所都与废物消毒系统相连。

官员们赞扬了习近平的这一努力。他们强调他的个人参与以及这如何体现了他对普通民众福祉的关心。官方媒体表示，该政策的成功证明了中国的政治实力。 “纵观人类历史，没有哪个国家、哪个政党能够在如此短的时间内动员全党全社会，自上而下地在全国范围内进行厕所革命，”全国性报纸《光明日报》援引一位中国人的话说。学者如是说。 “这是社会主义制度优越性的集中体现。”

人们可能会认为，习近平与该项目的密切联系会让官员们特别渴望做好这项工作。他的另一项运动旨在向官僚机构灌输“一致性意识”。这被定义为“坚定自觉地同共产党的领导和“以习近平同志为核心的人保持高度一致”。换句话说，那些违抗习近平指示或拖延执行指示的人可能会遇到麻烦。但在环卫工作方面，惊慌失措的官员并不一定是最有能力的。

来个废话

在中国的学术论文中，甚至在官方媒体上，都充斥着关于革命在某些地方如何出错的报道。该国较富裕的地区表现良好，但较贫困的地区则表现不佳。上个月在广元举行的会议上，官员们观看了国家电视台六月份播出的关于厕所问题的报道。 “为什么改善了的厕所却闲置了？”这是它的开场白。在对湖南省一个村庄里抱怨的居民（以及一位防卫的当地官员）进行采访的片段后，解说员提出了另一个问题：“这些炫耀的成就带来了什么结果？”农民们指责当地政府安装质量低劣，包括使用易碎的塑料管道，并在似乎没有进行适当检查的情况下证明工程足够。

因此，通常是自上而下的命令——在匆忙执行这些命令时，官员们习惯于忽视对质量的需求。在某种程度上，这是此类计划通常的融资方式的产物。中央政府支付部分工程费用，但让地方政府承担其余费用，通常比例要大得多。 2015年至2018年间，北京中央财政拨款约10亿元人民币（1.4亿美元）用于厕所改善。据中国媒体报道，来自地方政府和其他来源的资金是这一数额的 20 多倍。在不太富裕的地区，偷工减料自然更为常见。电视报道中出现的湖南村庄是该省最贫困的县之一。 “在一些地方，由于资金问题，他们不得不停止厕所改造项目，”中国出版物《智慧农业》杂志7月发表的一篇文章称。

官员们常常对这些任务采取千篇一律的做法，很少努力征求居民的意见，这无济于事。抽水马桶是习近平最喜欢的类型——官方媒体称，他在视察期间经常询问农村居民是否有抽水马桶。但由于急于取悦他，官僚们在向村民强加冲水厕所时有时会忽视气候和地理。在中国北方的严冬期间，管道很容易结冰，而且该国许多地区往往缺水。在东北辽宁省省会沉阳，周边农村2016年至2019年间新建的许多厕所因寒冷而无法使用。 2021 年，政府运营的新闻机构新华社称，过去五年，沉阳地区耗资 1 亿元人民币改造了 8 万个厕所，其中 5 万个因设计缺陷、施工不善或维护不足而废弃。 。 “一个惠民工程变成了一个痛彻心扉的工程，”该报告在谈到沉阳的经历时说道。

在全国各地，成年村民通常都是老年人，年轻人则进城务工。官员们很少花时间教老人们如何使用新厕所以及为什么需要它们。因此，随着村民恢复到熟悉的老式蹲式厕所，一些厕所最终很少被使用。 “大多数村民都有长期养成的如厕习惯，很难改变，”另一本中文期刊《农村经济与科技》 7月份的一篇文章称。 “一些村民认为抽水马桶需要额外的费用，认为投资是浪费钱……有些人甚至认为这是一个纯粹的美容项目……对‘厕所革命’不感兴趣。”

中共显然已决定让媒体更自由地报道厕所运动中遇到的困难，而不是通常情况下报道习近平所珍视的项目。可以推算一下：揭露不端行为、草率执行，影响不了他本人或党的形象，影响的只是地方领导人的​​形象。 4月份，农村部宣布今年厕所革命的重点是“提高质量”。检查员会被派往村庄，检查厕所的运行和维护情况（地方政府花钱建造更好的厕所，但往往不照顾它们）。

第二优先

在云南省，官员们仔细研究了过去几年的厕所革命记录，并对数千户家庭进行了调查。 7月，他们公布了调查结果：近33万户家庭没有收到全额的修建更好厕所的补贴。被谎报用于厕所维护和管理的资金超过450万元。专门用于革命的资金已被挪作他用。官方报告暗示，财务压力是罪魁祸首。部分资金被用于教育、医疗保健和住房。有一个县用它来偿还政府债务。在这个困难时期，它不可能是唯一的一个。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 14:01:38 GMT /内容/022rtifae3sns3k6pf9uc2eu9q7ifafe https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/09/xi-jinping-wants-china-to-have-better-toilets The people of Hong Kong are growing more tolerant

香港伊丽莎白女王体育馆通常举办相当单调的活动，例如辩论比赛。但在 11 月 4 日，当大约 1,500 名观众挥舞着彩虹旗时，竞技场上闪烁着荧光棒。在某些方面，同性恋运动会的开幕式与奥运会的开幕式类似， LGBT + 运动员与他们的同胞并肩游行（见图）。不过，同性恋运动会的气氛更加狂欢化。

这项为期一周的活动因疫情推迟了一年，现在来到香港，因为该市重新考虑性少数群体的权利。 9月，最高法院裁定当地政府必须纠正其未能提供“法律承认同性伴侣关系的替代框架”的问题，尽管它没有呼吁完全的婚姻平等。十月，另一家法院裁定支持同性伴侣平等继承权。

公众希望这座城市走得更远。今年早些时候的一项调查发现，60% 的香港人支持同性婚姻，高于十年前的 38%。观察人士表示，总体而言，人们的接受感正在增强。 “我看到街上越来越多的人手牵手，”游戏参与者 Shaun So 说道。

但并不是每个人都为奥运会铺上了彩虹地毯。保守派议员和反LGBT + 活动人士认为，他们颠覆了中国传统价值观，并由外国人资助，违反了香港的国家安全法。 （一个国际非营利组织负责举办比赛。）一些民主活动人士也反对这次活动。他们声称，在香港举办这个活动代表着对“负责镇压香港的非法政权”的公开拥抱。 （墨西哥瓜达拉哈拉是奥运会的共同主办国。）

自2019年香港遭遇民主抗议活动以来，中国加强了对这座城市的控制，限制民间社会并清除地方政府中的自由派人士。与2017年相比，没有公共资金用于举办奥运会，当时当地官员支持申办奥运会。一位活动人士表示，现在这些官员正在“根据他们对北京想要什么的猜测”做出决定。近年来，大陆政府让性少数群体的生活变得更加艰难，比如压制LGBT + 群体。

长期以来，香港一直以比内地更加开放和包容而自豪。当地政府没有提供帮助。但在LGBT +权利方面，这座城市仍然比亚洲大多数国家做得更好。至少，公众正在推动取得更多进展。 “我们需要保持耐心，”苏先生说。 “而且，就像马拉松一样，我们必须继续前进，永不放弃。” ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 14:01:38 GMT /内容/qm0ff6p57k3hu0tq7sv6vgsbm51hv497 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/09/the-people-of-hong-kong-are-grinding-more-宽容 China wants women to stay home and bear children

中国每五年召开一次全国妇女代表大会。就像中国一年一度的议会全体会议或共产党五年一次的代表大会一样，女性的聚会也是一场盛大的活动，在北京人民大会堂的红地毯上和华丽的吊灯下举行。很少有人对此给予太多关注。但在今年十月下旬举行的活动中，高层官员言论的微妙变化引起了一些人的关注。它们似乎证实了政府对妇女在社会中的角色的看法发生了转变。

几十年来，官员们在每次人大会议上都重申政府对男女平等的承诺，经常使用时任中国领导人江泽民在 1995 年引入的模板语言。但在今年会议的开幕词中，丁薛祥省略了标准措辞——或其任何版本。作为党的最高决策机构——政治局常务委员会委员，丁先生确实对女性提出了一些建议。他们应该学习中国领导人习近平的哲学，“树立正确的婚恋观、生育观、家庭观”。

10 月 30 日，习近平（如图）在另一场活动中向中华全国妇女联合会（党的领导机构）领导人发表讲话时，确实提到了“性别平等的基本国策”。但他没有提及职场或政府中的女性，或许是因为 24 名政治局委员中没有女性。习近平的讲话大部分时间都在谈论生育和家庭。他说，“我们要积极培育新型婚育文化”，并鼓励代表们“讲好家风故事”。这符合他对社会的保守看法。过去，习近平曾谈到“贤妻良母”的重要性，并提倡重男轻女的社会规范。

Recently, though, Mr Xi and his all-male coterie have started to sound a bit desperate. China needs women to have more babies in order to reverse a demographic decline that is likely to act as a drag on economic growth. For the first time since the 1960s, the country's population began shrinking last year. (Its working-age population started to decline in 2012.) The government is trying hard to reverse this trend. In 2016 it ditched its decades-old policy of limiting most couples to one child. In 2021 it adopted a three-children-per-couple policy.

But young people are still reluctant to marry and reproduce. A growing number of women are defying gender norms and choosing independent lifestyles. Many other youngsters, both men and women, are struggling to find jobs, let alone buy a house and start a family. Incentives to have children, such as cash handouts and tax breaks, have failed to convince couples that more kids are worth the cost. The average number of births per woman is well below that needed to maintain the population. Meanwhile, China is ageing rapidly, creating a huge burden of care.

Chinese women do not need to parse the rhetoric of officials to know that gender equality is no longer a priority for the party. Since Mr Xi assumed power in 2012, the situation has got progressively worse. The latest Global Gender Gap Index from the World Economic Forum, which measures progress towards parity between men and women, ranks China 107th out of 146 countries. In 2012 it ranked 69th out of 135. China's score has declined in several areas, such as educational attainment, political empowerment and health.

Xi, her, hers

Other big countries score worse (see chart), but China's fall in the ranking seems almost intentional, the result of an effort to push women back into traditional roles. There is something quite cynical about Mr Xi's vision, says Olivia Cheung of the School of Oriental and African Studies at the University of London. “Fundamentally, Xi Jinping sees women like everyone else in China,” she says: “mainly as risks to be controlled and resources to be harnessed for achieving the China dream.” ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 14:01:38 GMT /content/hoifj0jujt84q48fors1qk1u0ke2l1a5 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/09/china-wants-women-to-stay-home-and-bear-children A Chinese dispute with the Philippines is a test of America

T o grasp China’s approach to the international rule of law, look at the South China Sea. In recent weeks and months, large white-hulled ships belonging to China's coastguard have been bullying small boats sent to resupply a rusting ship-cum-garrison purposely grounded by the Philippines—an American treaty ally—on a disputed coral atoll two decades ago. China claims that atoll, the Second Thomas Shoal, as its own. At the same time, fighter jets from the People's Liberation Army ( PLA ) have repeatedly staged dangerously close intercepts of American reconnaissance flights in international skies close to China's coasts.

To justify such assertiveness, China offers convoluted claims about the history of the South China Sea and about international law that are rejected by almost all its maritime neighbours. To understand this apparently self-defeating strategy, the Broadway musical “Guys and Dolls” is an oddly helpful guide. Specifically, China's approach to geopolitics brings to mind Big Jule, a character in that peerless drama, first performed in 1950. A visitor from Chicago, Big Jule intimidates a cast of small-time New York gamblers with hints of ties to mobsters and glimpses of a gun under his coat. After losing a fortune on a dice game, Big Jule proposes a few more rounds, this time using his own custom dice, which are blank. “I had the spots taken off for luck. But I remember where the spots formerly were,” he explains, after patting his revolver meaningfully. Playing this version of the game, his outraged but fearful hosts proceed to lose large sums to Big Jule.

The link with Chinese statecraft involves Big Jule's use of spurious rules to get his way, rather than simply admitting to robbing fellow gamblers at gunpoint. There are no “Guys and Dolls” references in “China's Law of the Sea, The New Rules of Maritime Order”, a recent book by Isaac Kardon of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. Leaving that flaw aside, the book is a fine, deeply researched guide to China's efforts to subvert or reinterpret any principles that complicate its claims to more than four-fifths of the South China Sea. Citing Chinese official texts, Mr Kardon shows how the Communist Party sees international law as a “weapon”: a way to codify power relations between larger and smaller states, rather than a source of binding, universal norms.

In painstaking detail, the book records how soon after China signed the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea ( UNCLOS ) in 1982, officials in Beijing began passing laws that challenged the treaty. China applies rules for drawing maritime boundaries around rocks, reefs and far-flung islands in different ways, depending on whether features are Chinese-controlled or occupied by the troops or fishing fleets of its rivals. Chinese authorities forcefully defend exclusive fishing, mineral and navigation rights within 200 nautical miles of their territory, citing UNCLOS . At the same time, China routinely sends naval ships, fishing fleets and oil- and gas-survey vessels into waters that are just as close to other countries. (America upholds UNCLOS rules but is not a party to the convention.)

In 2016 the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague largely upheld a claim by the Philippines government that China's assertion of “historic rights” over swathes of the South China Sea is without legal basis. China calls that arbitral ruling a scrap of waste paper and continues to maintain and expand military bases on disputed reefs and artificial islands.

In its confrontation with the Philippines over the Second Thomas Shoal, China has given public warning that it will not allow boats to deliver building materials to shore up the crumbling hulk of the Sierra Madre , the beached ship used as a garrison by Filipino marines since 1999. Chinese coastguard cutters have used lasers and water cannon against supply boats, and collided with a Filipino vessel in October. The Philippines government released videos of these clashes. With American credibility as a treaty ally at stake, President Joe Biden said last month that any attack on Filipino aircraft, vessels or armed forces would trigger the two countries' “ironclad” mutual-defence commitments.

Sit down, you're rockin' the boat

To Chinese experts, it is self-evident that politics will decide these questions of international law. Zhou Bo, a retired PLA senior colonel now at Tsinghua University's Centre for International Security and Strategy, argues that China has been “restrained” at the Second Thomas Shoal and that the use of water cannon does not count as force. As a result he is sceptical of suggestions that America might escort Filipino convoys to the Sierra Madre , especially with conflicts raging in Ukraine and the Middle East. “Without the use of force, I think it would be difficult for the US to be provocative, especially with two wars going on in the world,” he says.

Against that, Hu Bo, a naval expert at Peking University, concedes that China faces a diplomatic dilemma at the Second Thomas Shoal, where neighbouring Asian countries may sympathise with the Philippines as the weaker party. “Right now, nobody cares about the truth and facts. Right now, people just say China has big ships and the Philippines has small ships,” he says.

As for mid-air intercepts, American arguments about its legal rights to fly and sail through international airspace and waters, and its calls for more “professionalism” from Chinese pilots, fall flat. “I consider a collision almost inevitable, given the high frequency of encounters,” says Mr Zhou. But if Chinese pilots stayed farther away, that would amount to “escorting America as it harms China's interests,” he insists.

The South China Sea is a dangerous and revealing place just now. Both China and America have every reason to avoid conflict there. But China yearns to expose America as an unreliable ally, and to make the Philippines obey Chinese-drawn red lines, or pay a visible price. To keep the peace, rules will be of less help than calculations of relative power and national interests. In this bleak world, Big Jule would be right at home. ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 14:01:38 GMT /content/2i3q5gssfoj6l1ndfe31pe6d5a88j7g5 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/09/a-chinese-dispute-with-the-philippines-is-a-test-of-america Xi Jinping is trying to fuse the ideologies of Marx and Confucius

K ARL MARX and Confucius may have lived 2,400 years apart, but on Chinese state television they stroll together through an ancient Chinese academy. In a sun-dappled bamboo grove, a group of student painters invite the two philosophers to be their models. As the young people paint, Marx and Confucius chat. They are impressed with China's high-speed trains, among other things. When the portraits are revealed, the thinkers are surprised. Marx is depicted in a Tang-dynasty robe; Confucius is portrayed in a Western suit and tie. But both are delighted. “I've been in China for more than a hundred years,” says Marx (in Mandarin). “Actually, I have been Chinese for a long time.” Confucius chuckles, stroking his beard. Long hair looks a bit strange with the suit, he says, but it make sense to keep changing.

The scene is from “When Marx Met Confucius”, a television series created by the propaganda department in Hunan province and released in October. It is not popular. On Douban, a film website, it has received only 100 or so reviews, most of them negative (eg, “makes me sick”). But for those who can stomach it, the show is a good way to understand Xi Jinping Thought on Culture, the latest branch of the Chinese leader's philosophy.

Other parts of Mr Xi's thinking emphasise tighter Communist Party control over such things as diplomacy, defence and the economy. Xi Jinping Thought on Culture, announced in October, attempts to fuse pride in Chinese tradition with loyalty to the party. Its most important tenet is the “two combines”, party-speak for a decades-long process to make Marxism more Chinese. The first combine refers to early efforts to adapt Marxism to China's “specific reality”. Such ideological flexibility allowed Deng Xiaoping, China's former leader, to pursue economic reforms in the 1980s. The second combine is Mr Xi's idea: to sinicise Marxism by melding it with traditional Chinese culture.

The effort represents the culmination of a radical turnaround for the party, which once considered tradition its enemy. During the Cultural Revolution of 1966-76, Mao Zedong's Red Guards destroyed Confucian temples, burnt Confucian texts and desecrated the sage's tomb. Young people denounced their elders, contradicting Confucianism's emphasis on filial piety. But after Mao's death in 1976 the party warmed to Confucius, or at least to a simplified version of his teachings that emphasises deference to authority. Deng allowed public celebrations of the philosopher's birthday. Jiang Zemin and Hu Jintao, Deng's successors, appropriated Confucian ideas. In the early 2000s Chinese scholars debated whether Confucianism might even replace Marxism as China's guiding ideology.

Mr Xi is putting an end to that debate. Marxism is the “soul” and Confucianism the “root” of Chinese culture, he says. Neither ideology can be abandoned. Instead, they must be merged.

“When Marx Met Confucius” guides viewers through this new thinking. For much of the five episodes, the philosophers sit on a stage in front of students and a rotating cast of scholars and party officials. A young woman wearing hanfu , traditional robes, plucks a guzheng , or ancient zither, in the background. The philosophers converse with holograms of figures such as Vladimir Lenin and Mao, who explain how their thinking is compatible. The programme's hosts then explain how it all fits into Xi Jinping Thought.

The show glosses over big differences between Confucius, who believed hierarchies were necessary to maintain social order, and Marx, who called for a proletarian revolution. “You were trying to maintain stability and I was seeking the liberation of all mankind,” says Marx. “But aren't we both seeking the greatest good for all humans?” When Marx mentions his vision of a classless society, Confucius says he has a comparable concept called datong (great unity). “So we have many similarities!” says Confucius. The students applaud.

The Cultural Revolution is mentioned—once. It did “great damage”, says a host. But Mao doesn't get the blame. At one point his spirit appears, assuring Marx and Confucius that he was a faithful communist and defender of traditional Chinese culture. Confucius nods approvingly.

The show spends more time bashing the West. A host blames foreign bullying of China in the 19th century for a “long-term cultural inferiority complex” (exacerbated by Chinese intellectuals, who at the time claimed China's traditions made it weak). The early reform era of the 1980s is remembered as a dangerous period of “historical nihilism”, when Western ideas misled Chinese people into criticising their society and government. “Can a country become strong if its economy develops but its spirit is lost?” asks the host, quoting Mr Xi.

No is the implicit answer. A good thing, then, that Mr Xi is restoring China's confidence, the show claims. Not only that, he and the party are pursuing the common good worldwide, in contrast to dastardly Western countries. America exports cluster bombs, while Japan dumps nuclear wastewater into the ocean, says a host. China, a “responsible great power”, would never do such things, he adds. Marx is impressed. He congratulates China for revitalising socialism and fulfilling his vision.

“When Marx Met Confucius” is easy to ridicule, but parts of its message are worrying. In the last episode, a student asks Confucius for advice on Taiwan, the self-governing island that China claims. “We truly have a traditional culture of peace, but some Western countries only believe in the law of the jungle,” says the student. “If they bully us or obstruct our national unification, should we still speak to them of peace?” Confucius furrows his brow. Goodness should be met with goodness, but hatred should be met with justice, he says. A host jumps in. China seeks peace, but if its dignity and interests are hurt, it will use military force to pursue national unification, he says. Images of fighter jets and warships fill the screen. ■

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:17:57 GMT /content/l8slgmcqqqrsfpqm8qq1ois2n4dtegl8 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/02/xi-jinping-is-trying-to-fuse-the-ideologies-of-marx-and-confucius China and Bhutan aim to resolve a long-running border dispute

C hinese diplomats have had a rough ride in South Asia for most of the past four years. Relations with India took a nosedive after a deadly border clash in 2020. Debt problems, political instability and militant attacks on Chinese nationals have strained an “ironclad” friendship with Pakistan. Mass unrest toppled a China-friendly president in Sri Lanka last year after it plunged into a debt crisis linked to Chinese lending. Bangladesh also shelved several infrastructure projects tied to China's Belt and Road Initiative.

Lately, though, China has bounced back in some of the region—to India's dismay. The most recent Chinese success came with Bhutan, a Himalayan kingdom of 770,000 people wedged between China and India. It is the only Asian country without formal diplomatic ties to China. Along with India, it is also one of only two countries whose land borders with China are officially disputed. And to complicate matters further, the disagreement covers an area, known as the Doklam plateau, where the Indian, Chinese and Bhutanese borders meet (see map).

The breakthrough was the first ever visit to Beijing by a Bhutanese foreign minister. Tandi Dorji met his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, on October 23rd (see picture) and China's vice-president, Han Zheng, the following day. He also participated in the two countries' first talks on the frontier dispute since a stand-off between Chinese and Indian troops in Doklam in 2017.

In his meeting, Mr Wang said China was ready to complete the border talks as soon as possible and to establish formal ties with Bhutan, describing it as a “historic opportunity”. China's readout quoted Mr Dorji saying he too was keen for an early border settlement and progress towards establishing formal ties. A joint press release was less forthright, saying just that the two sides agreed to continue pushing forward with the border negotiations.

But Bhutan's prime minister, Lotay Tshering, suggested to an Indian newspaper earlier in October that the end goal was formal ties with China. “Theoretically, how can Bhutan not have any bilateral relations with China? The question is when, and in what manner,” he said. He also mentioned that a possible land swap involving Doklam had been proposed.

The rapprochement is geopolitically important for several reasons. Bhutan does not have formal diplomatic ties with any of the five permanent members (or P 5) of the UN Security Council—America, Britain, China, France and Russia—largely owing to its history of isolationism and non-alignment in the cold war. Opening formal ties with China could lead Bhutan to do the same with other P 5 members, drawing it into the ongoing tussle for diplomatic influence around China's borders.

But it is most significant for India. Under a treaty signed in 1949, India gained a formal right to guide Bhutan's foreign policy in exchange for free trade and security guarantees. The foreign-policy provision was scrapped in 2007, but India has remained Bhutan's most important diplomatic and economic partner.

Indian officials' chief concern is Doklam because it is near the Siliguri corridor (also known as “the chicken's neck”) which connects India's north-eastern states to the rest of the country. Indian authorities have long feared that China, which won a brief border war with India over a nearby part of the disputed frontier in 1962, might try to sever the Siliguri corridor.

India may now have accepted that diplomatic ties between China and Bhutan are inevitable, given the lure of Chinese trade and investment. But it wants a role in the border talks and is sceptical about a land swap. Progress might still be possible, given that China and India both seem keen to stabilise their border dispute. Since the deadly clash in 2020, they have pulled back troops from several flashpoints, creating buffer zones where neither side patrols.

But Indian officials also have concerns about China's renewed efforts to enhance its clout in a region that India considers its backyard. Several South Asian states are indebted to China. The Maldives, where India had recently reasserted its influence, elected a new pro-China president, Mohamed Muizzu, in September. He has since asked India to remove the roughly 70 Indian troops stationed there to maintain radar stations and other military assets.

In Sri Lanka, too, India has pushed back against China's influence in recent years, but the island nation has lately indicated that it seeks strong relations with both of Asia's giants. On October 25th Sri Lanka's government allowed a Chinese scientific-research vessel to dock in Colombo, its biggest city, despite American and Indian security concerns. Sri Lanka's president, Ranil Wickremesinghe, also attended the Belt and Road Forum in Beijing in October. The geopolitical jockeying is sure to continue. But China is still very much in the game. ■

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:17:57 GMT /content/daf6fe8f5m3482ilh7grk3uqossfb0on https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/02/china-and-bhutan-aim-to-resolve-a-long-running-border-dispute How China’s delivery drivers quietly fight to improve their lot

C hina's food-delivery drivers have a lot to complain about. Many work long days, earning as little as 5 yuan ($0.68) per delivery. Heavy rain and heatwaves do not stop them—in fact, demand is highest during such weather. Delivery apps promise fast turnarounds, so drivers, most of whom work for contractors, are sometimes fined for arriving late (not to mention scolded by customers). The only way to keep up, they say, is by running red lights and speeding. Accidents are common.

Drivers and couriers have pressed for improvements, holding around 400 protests in the past five years, says China Labour Bulletin, an NGO in Hong Kong. Perceived troublemakers can face consequences, such as being cut out of deliveries. Nevertheless, a new study suggests that labour activism among drivers may actually be more widespread than previously thought. Some are using quieter tactics to get their way.

The research was carried out by Bo Zhao of Fudan University in Shanghai and Siqi Luo of Sun Yat-sen University in Guangzhou. One of the authors spent 18 months working as a delivery driver in southern China. During this time they witnessed five small-scale strikes, none of which was known to the public. Rather than taking to the streets, upset drivers simply logged out of the app that assigns deliveries during a period when demand was high, such as at lunchtime. That was enough to cause delays to snowball, forcing the company to reject orders.

Even the threat of such action causes some supervisors to bend rules on when drivers get fined, says the study. Another piece of research, from 2021, found that small-scale strikes were sometimes effective in convincing contractors to increase (slightly) how much they pay.

It helps when the public gets involved. In 2021 a company called Ele.me said it could pay only 2,000 yuan ($273) in compensation to the family of a delivery worker who died on the job. After a backlash on social media, the company agreed to cough up 600,000 yuan. Later that year, the government demanded that delivery companies improve working conditions for drivers and couriers. But little has actually changed, says China Labour Bulletin.

More organised and ambitious labour activism would probably lead to more gains for workers. But the Chinese government is unlikely to tolerate it. For years Chen Guojiang, a food-delivery driver in Beijing, posted videos online trying to drum up support. At one point he said he was talking to 14,000 drivers via groups on WeChat, a messaging service. He encouraged them to work together and fight for better conditions. That was too much for the authorities. In 2021 he was arrested for “picking quarrels and provoking trouble”, a vague charge commonly used to punish activists. Small, quiet victories may be the best drivers can hope for. ■

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:17:57 GMT /content/2u4obldhkokck6k708lp1c45dimmgr52 https://www.economist.com/china/2023/11/02/how-chinas-delivery-drivers-quietly-fight-to-improve-their-lot Why Chinese mourn Li Keqiang, their former prime minister

T he umbrellas gave them away. Even from a distance, these were unmistakably townsfolk, shielding themselves with parasols from an autumn sun that no Chinese farmer would fear. On and on they trudged: a long column of outsiders, following a country lane between rice paddies and fishponds towards the village of Jiuzi, ancestral home of Li Keqiang, China's prime minister until his retirement earlier this year.

They were mourners, turning out in their hundreds on this warm Sunday, a few days after Li's sudden death at the age of 68. Most held bunches of white and yellow chrysanthemums, a funeral flower in China. Under their umbrellas some were formally dressed in black and white. Parents cajoled young children to keep walking, after parking cars in fields well outside the village.

No Communist Party diktat had summoned these grieving citizens. Nor had convoys of buses brought them. Quite the opposite. Official media outlets have played down Li's death. Instead, state media have devoted their efforts—as always—to extolling Xi Jinping. China's leader has spent more than a decade concentrating power in his own hands, at the expense of government ministries and of Li Keqiang, who oversaw them as prime minister. The diminishing of Li continues even after his demise. Though terse, his official obituary finds room for four tributes to the leadership of the party central committee “with Xi Jinping at the core”.

For days, censors have deleted large numbers of online tributes to Li, leaving only the blandest untouched. Reports abound of universities banning students from organising memorials. There is a grim logic to this caution. More than once, a public figure's passing has offered Chinese citizens a chance to stage demonstrations, notably after a former party boss, Hu Yaobang, died in 1989.

For all that discouragement, thousands of Chinese have persisted in leaving flowers and handwritten notes for Li, from Jiuzi to cities where he lived and worked, such as Hefei and Zhengzhou. Some observers, including Chinese intellectuals outside the country, detect in these tributes a challenge to Mr Xi, and a yearning for a more reformist China. One exiled writer calls this moment a “flowers revolution”. Such intellectuals remember Li's youth as a brilliant law student at Peking University, with an interest in Western legal systems (he helped to translate a book on the rule of law by Lord Denning, a British judge). They are undaunted by Li's actual record as prime minister from 2013 to 2023. True, they concede, that decade saw the party systematically dismantle checks and balances on its power, and spurn the rule of law in favour of an iron-fisted alternative that Mr Xi calls “law-based governance”. But in their telling, Li's humiliations make him an icon for others whose hopes have been crushed in Xi-era China.

Chaguan is not about to tell Chinese exiles they are mistaken about their own country. Indeed, despite the censors' best efforts, social-media users have circulated images of floral tributes and graffiti that do look like anti-Xi complaints. Many of these quote celebrated Li sayings, in particular his pledge that China's opening to the world is as irreversible as the flow of the Yangzi and Yellow rivers. It is safe to assume the intention is to grumble about the inward-looking nationalism of the Xi era.

For all that, it would be unfair to claim that every mourner for Li is a protester. When this columnist visited Jiuzi, the crowds were on their best behaviour, not defiant or fearful, as would be expected at an actual demonstration in China. Local farmers sold cut-up sugar cane to visitors, as police directed traffic. When asked why they had come, several mourners offered apolitical answers about a local man who reached the top.

A mother who had brought her young son to lay flowers praised Li as “a good premier who did practical things for the people”. Yet listen carefully, and some of that cautious praise was revealing. The mother noted that Li went to the epicentre of the covid-19 pandemic, Wuhan, “at the earliest possible time”. She did not mention that Mr Xi took months to visit Wuhan and never visits natural disasters while they are under way. Perhaps the mother was not thinking of this. But it is a common gripe.

Several people in Jiuzi noted that Li, the son of a rural official, knew poverty as a child. To them, this explained Li's focus on concrete problems, such as migrant workers not being paid wages they are owed. One man contrasted Li's humble origins with Mr Xi's background, as the son of a party elder and Politburo member.

Around China, sites linked to Mr Xi and his family have been lavishly restored as “red tourism” destinations for party pilgrims. In Jiuzi, a farmer recalled talk of beautifying the village after Li achieved high office. But whenever their illustrious ex-neighbour heard of special treatment for Jiuzi, he “would call and tell the local officials not to do it,” the farmer said approvingly.

The death of accountability

Two seemingly disparate groups—angry dissenters and nominally apolitical families laying flowers in Jiuzi—do in fact overlap. The link involves accountability and Li's willingness to admit that China still has serious problems. At a press conference in 2020, Li shocked some urbanites by reminding them that around 600m Chinese subsist on just 1,000 yuan ($137) a month. He also admitted that covid had hit poor families hard. At other times he called for checks on arbitrary government power and for the public to supervise officials' work. Many Chinese recall those Li sayings now. They are making a political point whether they admit it or not.

As a reform-era technocrat, Li served a one-party system that sought legitimacy through governing performance. Many Chinese miss that time. That is surely what they mean when they call Li practical and in touch with the masses. Today China has one-man rule and the party rejects external supervision. To admit to problems in this China is to doubt Mr Xi: an impossibility. China will be mourning that loss of accountability for a long time to come. ■
